Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Relative Controls of Niche vs. Neutral Microbial Community Assembly Processes Over Ecosystem Function Post-Disturbance
Award.AbstractNarration:
Is it necessary to know what types of microbes are present in a system in order to understand and predict ecosystem processes? This is a fundamental, yet unanswered, question. This project will address hypotheses regarding the relationship between community assembly processes, environmental parameters and ecosystem functioning following a disturbance. Soil microbial community structure and function will be tracked in soils at various times after forest fires. Phylogenetic and genomic approaches will be employed to explore the factors controlling how microbial communities develop, and the relative roles of different controls in structuring microbial communities. This work will also focus on describing the temporal and spatial dynamics of the well-documented changes in nitrogen cycling that are observed following wildfires. This research is expected to build a better understanding of the contributions of microbial community structuring to these important soil processes.

This study will focus on how soil communities recover from burning at a time when fire frequency and severity are escalating across the American West. The project will also facilitate the development and refinement of new bioinformatics approaches to analyze the large data sets required to study the dynamics of complex microbial communities. Broader impacts include the training of graduate students and a post-doctoral scholar, and the development of a course to integrate undergraduates directly into the planned research. Additionally, outreach will be conducted at a local high school with a high proportion of at-risk students
.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Microbes are ubiquitous and essential for the proper functioning of all ecosystems. However, we know relatively little about how ecological communities of microorganisms assemble themselves, especially after ecological disturbance events. The goal of this collaborative grant, between Duke University, Georgia Institute of Technology, and University of Colorado, is to improve our understanding of post-disturbance microbial community assembly mechanisms. Towards this goal, the research team used a combination of environmental sampling and analysis, modeling, and laboratory microcosms to study microbial community patterns and dynamics following various disturbances.

This outcome report focuses on the findings from microcosm-based research, led by Dr. Lin Jiang at Georgia Tech, which explored the ecological assembly and evolutionary changes of bacterial, fungal, and protozoan communities after different types of disturbance, including environmental warming, habitat fragmentation, acidification, sonication, and nanoparticle pollution. These research activities have shown that disturbance can have significant, and sometimes unexpected, consequences at both ecological and evolutionary time scales. For example, while environmental warming and habitat fragmentation are generally known to reduce biodiversity, the research team demonstrated experimentally that habitat fragmentation could actually increase the number of species that coexist with each other relative to a large unfragmented habitat, and that habitat fragmentation could slow the pace of species extinction in the face of environmental warming. As another example, the research team has found that the pollution of nanoparticles, which are being increasingly used in various industries, could inhibit the diversification of Pseudomonas fluorescens SBW-25, a bacterium found on plant leaves, and could promote the formation and cluster size of multicellular mutations of Baker’s yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae Y55.   

An important component of this research program was to provide training for future scientists in ecological research. During the four-year period, this project has trained one research scientist, four graduate students, and six undergraduate students (including one African American student). These individuals gained valuable experience in experimental design, data collection and analysis, and manuscript writing.

This project has produced a total of 20 publications in peer-reviewed journals.
